An email was sent to Little Miami families this afternoon with a draft of the district's Return to Learn plan for the 2020-2021 school year.

Three important take-aways:
The plan contains two options for students: face-to-face instruction in LM buildings or remote learning through a third-party vendor.

Safety protocols are key to staff and students returning to -- and staying in -- our buildings safely. Safety protocols include health assessments, cleaning and disinfecting, social distancing and the wearing of face coverings.

The student calendar has changed slightly, pending Board approval. First day for grades 5-12 will be Aug. 17. First day for grades PreK-4 will be Aug. 19. No other changes have been made to the calendar.

Additional information will be coming soon.

Issue 10 FAQs: Don’t school districts get more tax money with every new house that gets built?
A. By law, an operating levy can only be collected for the amount approved by voters. This levy was locked in at $10.6 million in 2011 and has remained that amount since, no matter how many houses are built. However, the millage needed to generate those dollars has decreased, from 13.95 in 2011 to 9.92 for Issue 10. More residents means more properties to share the tax burden, and a decrease in the amount each property owner must pay. Issue 10 is a renewal of the $10.6 million levy and is not a new tax.

Issue 10 FAQs: Wasn’t Little Miami just on the ballot recently?
Little Miami voters approved a bond issue in May 2018. By law, bond dollars can only be used for construction, not day-to-day operations. The 2018 bond issue is paying for additions to the intermediate, junior high and high school, and a new PreK/K/1 building. Issue 10 will replace an operating levy that is expiring at the end of 2020 and is not a new tax.

Issue 10 FAQs: Why does Little Miami need this renewal?
Issue 10 will replace a levy that is expiring at the end of 2020. The amount collected from this levy is $10.6 million annually and represents one-fifth of Little Miami’s budget for day-to-day operations. The original levy was approved in 2011, and then was renewed by voters in 2015. Issue 10 is a request for another renewal, and is not a new tax.

post_text: Issue 10 FAQs: What is a substitute levy? A substitute levy is the only type of ballot issue that can replace an emergency levy and can be for 5 years, 10 years or continuous. Issue 10 is a continuous levy. A substitute levy allows a school district to collect a small amount of increased property tax revenue from any new construction that occurs inside district boundaries during each tax year. And since this is a renewal and not considered a “new” levy, qualifying property owners will keep the 12.5% in tax reimbursement they currently receive.

More than 230 middle school students from around Cincinnati and Columbus came to Little Miami Junior High Saturday for the regional Power of the Pen competition.

Power of the Pen is an interscholastic creative writing program for middle schools. During competitions, students are given a writing prompt and 40 minutes to complete a fully-developed piece of creative writing.

Not only did the junior high host the competition, but the LMJH 7th grade team took first place! Congrats to coach Erin Dipzinski and to her team of talented writers.
